discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
If the source and destination IP are set to "any", then A would be corect.
I would assign the port range to be sure 1-65535.
Therefore, I select B.

Selected Answer: B
According to the link below, there is no "blank object" and in order to cover all ports, you have to put in the range 1-65535
This is why I am using B
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/firepower/710/fdm/fptd-fdm-config-guide-710/fptd-fdm-objects.html#task_49CC5243743F4921AAF00CF6AB0264BE

comments.content: though the wording of "define"it is more related to a custom Object type, than an already existing one - which is UDP

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A looks fine.
I verified in lab and confirmed UDP Port Object with empty port number can be added.

choices.C: Add the transport number and specify the type and code.
choices.D: Add the corresponding IP protocol number for UDP and TCP.
choices.B: Define the transport protocol and the mandatory port range.
choices.A: Specify the transport protocol and leave the port number empty.

questions.question_text: A security engineer must add a new policy to block UDP traffic to one server. The engineer adds a new object. Which action must the engineer take next to identify all the UDP ports?

//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer is configuring access control rules on a Cisco Secure Firewall Threat Defense device. The access control rules must include a file policy with rules that will trigger when MSEXE files are accessed. Which two actions must be configured in the access rule? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
You can associate a single file policy with an access control rule whose action is Allow, Interactive Block, or Interactive Block with reset.

comments.content:
According to this doc it seems it could:
"Access Control Rule Monitor Action

The Monitor action is not designed to permit or deny traffic. Rather, its primary purpose is to force connection logging, regardless of how matching traffic is eventually handled.

If a connection matches a Monitor rule, the next non-Monitor rule that the connection matches should determine traffic handling and any further inspection. If there are no additional matching rules, the system should use the default action. "

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/firepower/610/configuration/guide/fpmc-config-guide-v61/access_control_rules.html#ID-2190-0000023b
And from the link above, I will go with C and D actually, in the ACP
i will go for C and D as well.

You have most probably got that result because you were putting the Block statement, before the File/Intrusion Policies so there was no any other possible action on the flow to be made because it became discarded

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
Definitely not AC. The answer is BD.

I have verified in my lab that if you set the ACP action to A/C/E, the File Policy (and Intrusion Policy) is automatically set to "None" and cannot be changed.
File Policy can only be set when ACP actions are B and D.

choices.A: Disable all the DHCP Snort rules by using Secure Firewall Device Manager.
choices.C: Disable Option 82 in the DHCP relay configuration properties using Secure Firewall Management Center.
choices.D: Add access rules that allow DHCP traffic by using Cisco Secure Firewall Management Center.
choices.B: Add another DHCP pool on Server_A with DHCP relay on Secure Firewall Threat Defense.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer is deploying a new instance of Cisco Secure Firewall Threat Defense. Which action must the engineer take next so that Client_A and Client_B receive an IP address via DHCP from Server_A?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Correct Answer: D
For features that are not directly supported on the transparent firewall, you can allow traffic to pass through so that upstream and downstream routers can support the functionality. For example, by using an access rule, you can allow DHCP traffic (instead of the unsupported DHCP relay feature) or multicast traffic such as that created by IP/TV.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/firepower/70/configuration/guide/fpmc-config-guide-v70/transparent_or_routed_firewall_mode_for_firepower_threat_defense.html

choices.B: LDAPS server certificate must be added to Secure Firewall Management Center realms
choices.D: LDAPS server certificate must be added to Secure Firewall Threat Defense
choices.A: Secure Firewall Threat Defense certificate must be added to the LDAPS server
choices.C: Secure Firewall Management Center certificate must be added to the LDAPS server

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
If you use FMC you add it on the FMC

Selected Answer: D
FTD does the authN, not FMC

Selected Answer: B
The certificate must be added to FMC realm

comments.content:
I don't know if you had a typo, but it is on the FMC. 
Correct Answer: B
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/security/anyconnect-secure-mobility-client-v4x/220880-configure-password-management-using-ldap.html#toc-hId--2065014694:~:text=NTDS%5CPersonal.-,FMC%20Configurations,-Verify%20Licensing

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Correct Answer: D
import the Root CA Certificate that has signed the LDAPS service Certificate on the Windows Server under Objects > PKI > Trusted CAs > Add Trusted CA, as this is referenced under theDirectory Server Configuration of the Realm

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/security/anyconnect-secure-mobility-client-v4x/220880-configure-password-management-using-ldap.html#toc-hId--2065014694

questions.question_text: A VPN administrator converted an instance of Cisco Secure Firewall Threat Defense, which is managed by Cisco Secure Firewall Management Center, from using LDAP to LDAPS for remote access VPN authentication. Which certificate must be added to allow for remote users to authenticate over the VPN?

A network administrator is configuring a transparent Cisco Secure Firewall Threat Defense registered to a Cisco Secure Firewall Management Center. The administrator wants to configure the Secure Firewall Threat Defense to allow ARP traffic to pass between two interfaces of a bridge group. What must be configured?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Correct Answer: A

By default, all ARP packets are passed within the bridge group.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/secure-firewall/management-center/device-config/760/management-center-device-config-76/device-ops-tfw.html

choices.B: An access policy must allow MAC address 0100.0CCC.CCCD.
choices.A: Use the default configuration on the devices.
choices.D: An access policy must allow MAC address FFFF.FFFF.FFFF.
